01.text: The writer returns to the theme, which he began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:01|8:1]], of Jesus healing people. This begins an account of Jesus healing a paralyzed man.
It is implied that the disciples were with Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is probably the same boat as in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:23|8:23]]. You only need to specify this if needed to avoid confusion.
"to the town where he lived." This refers to Capernaum.
This marks the beginning of another event in the larger story. It may involve different people than the previous events. Your language may have a way of showing this.
This refers to the faith of the men and may also include the faith of the paralyzed man.
The man was not Jesus' real son. Jesus was speaking to him politely. If this is confusing, it can also be translated "My friend" or "Young man" or even omitted.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I have forgiven your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

03.text: This marks the beginning of another event in the larger story. It may involve different people than the previous events. Your language may have a way of doing this.
Possible meanings are 1) each one was thinking to himself, or 2) they were speaking among themselves.
Jesus was claiming to be able to do things the scribes thought only God can do.
Jesus knew what they were thinking either supernaturally or because he could see them talking to each other.

03.ref: Why are you thinking evil in your hearts?
03.text: Jesus used this question to rebuke the scribes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is moral evil or wickedness, not simply error in fact.
Here "hearts" refers to their minds or their thoughts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

03.ref: For which is easier to say, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Get up and walk'?
03.text: Jesus uses a question to challenge the scribes. He does not mean one action is harder for him than the other. He is reminding the scribes that they believe when God heals a person's body it means he has forgiven them of their sins. AT: "For you know it is just as easy to say, 'Your sins are forgiven,' as it is to say, 'Get up and walk'." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

03.ref: which is easier to say, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Get up and walk'?
03.text: This can be translated as an indirect quotation. AT: "it is just as easy to tell a person his sins are forgiven as it is to tell him to get up and walk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Here "your" is singular. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I have forgiven your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"I will prove to you." The "you" is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Jesus is not forbidding the man to go elsewhere. He is giving the man the opportunity to go home.

07.text: This concludes the account of Jesus healing a paralyzed man. Jesus then calls a tax collector to be one of his disciples.
This refers to the authority to declare sins forgiven.

07.ref: As Jesus passed by from there
07.text: This phrase marks the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
Church tradition says that this Matthew is the author of this Gospel, but the text gives no reason to change the pronouns from "him" and "He" to "me" and "I."

07.ref: He got up and followed him
07.text: "Matthew got up and followed Jesus." This means Matthew became Jesus' disciple.

10.text: These events occur at the house of Matthew the tax collector.
This is probably Matthew's house, but it could also be Jesus' house. Specify only if needed to avoid confusion.
This marks the beginning of another event in the larger story. It may involve different people than the previous events. Your language may have a way of doing this.
"When the Pharisees saw that Jesus was eating with the tax collectors and sinful people"

10.ref: Why does your teacher eat with tax collectors and sinful people?
10.text: The Pharisees use this question to criticize what Jesus is doing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

12.text: These events occur at the house of Matthew the tax collector.
Here "this" refers to the question the Pharisees asked about Jesus eating with tax collectors and sinners.

12.ref: People who are strong in body do not need a physician, only those who are sick
12.text: Jesus answers with a proverb. He means that he eats with these kinds of people because he has come to help sinners. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])

12.ref: People who are strong in body

12.text: The phrase "need a physician" is understood. AT: "people who are sick need a physician" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

12.ref: You should go learn what this means
12.text: Jesus is about to quote the scriptures. AT: "You should learn the meaning of what God said in the scriptures"
Here "you" is plural and refers to the Pharisees. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

12.ref: I desire mercy and not sacrifice
12.text: Jesus is quoting what the prophet Hosea wrote in the scriptures. Here, "I" refers to God.
Jesus is using irony. He does not think there are any people who are righteous and do not need to repent. AT: "those who think they are righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

14.text: The disciples of John the Baptist question the fact that Jesus' disciples do not fast.

14.ref: Can wedding attendants be sorrowful while the bridegroom is still with them?
14.text: Jesus uses a question to answer John's disciples. They all knew that people do not mourn and fast at a wedding celebration. Jesus uses this proverb to show that his disciples do not mourn because he is still there with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])

14.ref: the bridegroom will be taken away from them
14.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the bridegroom will not be able to be with them any longer" or "someone will take the bridegroom away from them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Jesus is probably referring to his own death, but this should not be made explicit here in the translation. To maintain the imagery of a wedding, it is best to just state that the bridegroom will not be there any longer.

16.text: Jesus continues to answer the question that the disciples of John had asked.

16.ref: No man puts a piece of new cloth on an old garment
16.text: This proverb means that people who know only the old traditions are not eager to accept new ones. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])
"the piece of new cloth." This is the piece of cloth used to cover a hole in the old garment.

16.ref: and a worse tear will be made
16.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and this will make the tear worse" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

17.text: Jesus continues to answer the question that disciples of John had asked.

17.ref: Neither do people put new wine into old wineskins
17.text: Jesus uses another proverb to answer John's disciples. This means the same as the proverb in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:09:16|9:16]].
"Neither does anyone pour" (UDB) or "People never put"
This refers to wine that has not fermented yet. If grapes are unknown in your area, use the general term for fruit. AT: "grape juice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
This refers to wineskins that have been used many times.
"wine bags" or "skin bags" (UDB). These were bags made out of animal skins.

17.ref: the wine will be spilled, and the wineskins will be destroyed
17.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and this will ruin the wineskin and spill the wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
When the new wine ferments and expands, the skins tear open because they can no longer stretch out.
"new wineskins" or "new wine bags." This refers to wineskins that no one has used.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "this will keep safe both the wineskin and the wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

18.text: This begins an account of Jesus bringing to life the daughter of a Jewish official after she had died.
This refers to the answer Jesus gave John's disciples about fasting.
The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this.
This is a way someone would show respect in Jewish culture. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

18.ref: come and lay your hand on her, and she will live
18.text: This shows that the Jewish official believed Jesus had the power to bring his daughter back to life.

20.text: This describes how Jesus healed another woman while he was on the way to the Jewish official's house.
The word "Behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this.

"had a severe flow of blood." She was probably bleeding from her womb even when it was not the normal time for it. Some cultures may have a polite way of referring to this condition. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

20.ref: For she had said to herself, "If only I touch his clothes, I will be made well"
20.text: She thought this before she touched Jesus. You can put this statement earlier as in the UDB. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])

20.ref: If only I touch his clothes
20.text: According to Jewish law, because she was bleeding she was not supposed to touch anyone. She touches his clothes so that Jesus' power would heal her and yet (she thought) he would not know that she touched him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Instead." What the woman hoped would happen did not happen.
The woman was not Jesus' real daughter. Jesus was speaking to her politely. If this is confusing, it can also be translated "Young woman" or even omitted.

20.ref: Your faith has made you well
20.text: "Because you believed in me, I will heal you"

20.ref: the woman was healed from that hour
20.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus healed her at that moment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

23.text: This returns to the account of Jesus bringing the daughter of the Jewish official back to life.
This is the Jewish leader's house.

23.ref: the flute players and the crowds making much noise
23.text: This is a common way to mourn for someone who has died.
Jesus was speaking to many people, so use the plural command form if your language has one.

23.ref: the girl is not dead, but she is asleep
23.text: Jesus is using a play on words. It was common in Jesus' day to refer to a dead person as one who "sleeps." But here the dead girl will get up, as though she had only been sleeping. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

25.text: This completes the account of Jesus bringing the daughter of the Jewish official back to life.
Verse 26 is a summary statement that describes the result of Jesus raising this girl from the dead.

25.ref: When the crowd had been put outside
25.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "After Jesus had sent the crowd outside" or "After the family had sent the people outside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"got out of bed." This is the same meaning as in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:14|8:15]].

25.ref: The news about this spread into all that region
25.text: "The people of that whole region heard about it" (UDB) or "The people who saw that the girl was alive started telling everyone in the whole area about it"

27.text: This begins the account of Jesus healing two blind men.

27.ref: As Jesus passed by from there
27.text: As Jesus was leaving the region
This means they were walking behind Jesus, not necessarily that they had become his disciples.
It is implied that they wanted Jesus to heal them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Jesus was not David's literal son, so this may be translated as "Descendant of David" (UDB). However, "Son of David" is also a title for the Messiah, and the men were probably calling Jesus by this title.

27.ref: When Jesus had come into the house
27.text: This could be either Jesus' own house (UDB) or the house in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:09:10|9:10]].
The full content of their answer is not stated, but it is understood. AT: "Yes, Lord, we believe you can heal us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

29.text: It is not clear whether he touched both men's eyes at the same time or used only his right hand to touch one then the other. As the left hand was customarily used for unclean purposes, it is most likely that he used only his right hand. It is also not clear whether he spoke as he was touching them or touched them first and then spoke to them.

29.ref: Let it be done to you according to your faith
29.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will do as you have believed" or "Because you believe, I will heal you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This means they were able to see. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God healed their eyes" or "the two blind men were able to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

29.ref: See that no one knows about this
29.text: Here "See" means "be sure." AT: "Be sure no one finds out about this" or "Do not tell anyone that I healed you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Instead." The men did not do what Jesus told them to do.
"told many people what had happened to them"

32.text: This is the account of Jesus healing a demon-possessed man who could not speak and how people responded.
The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this.

32.ref: a mute man ... was brought to Jesus
32.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone brought a mute man ... to Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom a demon had possessed" or "whom a demon was controlling" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

32.ref: When the demon had been driven out
32.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "After Jesus had forced the demon out" or "After Jesus had commanded the demon to leave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the mute man began to speak" or "the man who had been mute spoke" or "the man, who was no longer mute, spoke"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "This has never happened before" or "No one has ever done anything like this before" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

35.text: Verse 35 is the end of the part of the story that began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:01|8:1]] about Jesus' healing ministry in Galilee. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
Verse 36 begins a new part of the story where Jesus teaches his disciples and sends them to preach and heal as he has done.
Jesus went to many or most of the cities but not necessarily every one of them. AT: "many of the cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"large villages ... small villages" or "large towns ... small towns"
Here "kingdom" refers to God's rule as king. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:04:23|4:23]].

35.ref: all kinds of disease and all kinds of sickness
35.text: "every disease and every sickness." The words "disease" and "sickness" are closely related but should be translated as two different words if possible. "Disease" is what causes a person to be sick. "Sickness" is the physical weakness or affliction that results from having a disease.

35.ref: They were like sheep without a shepherd
35.text: This simile means they did not have a leader to take care of them. AT: "The people did not have a leader" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

37.text: Jesus uses a proverb about harvesting to tell his disciples how they should respond to the needs of the crowds mentioned in the previous section.

37.ref: The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few
37.text: Jesus uses a proverb to respond to what he is seeing. Jesus means there are a lot of people who are ready to believe God but only few people to teach them God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])
"There is plenty of ripe food for someone to collect"

37.ref: pray to the Lord of the harvest
37.text: "pray to God, because he is in charge of the harvest"
